Rumors floating around painted Gaius Aetius Paullus as a paranoid tyrant or a benevolent despot, but the man standing in front of you appears to be neither paranoid nor benevolent.
He has an unmistakable aura of power and authority as do all men who are accustomed to being obeyed without question. In his world, his word is the law.
“At ease, soldier,” says Paullus, studying you. “You’ve made quite a name for yourself. Killed Antidas and his guards in his own palace. Must have been one hell of a fight.”
“At ease, soldier,” says Paullus, studying you. “You’ve made quite a name for yourself. The alliance with Antidas, was that your idea?”
“A smart move. Carrinas would be much easier to deal with had he stood alone with Antidas’ blood on his hands.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What makes you think it was me?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“Diplomacy was never one of Carrinas’ strongest suits. He would have simply killed Antidas and called it a day. Since he sent *you* to Maadoran, I assumed that you’re behind this idea.
“And the fight at the pass... I wouldn’t have believed it, had Carbo not been there to witness it. You have a gift, <charname>. Some people are born to plow soil. Some people are born to kill. You can do both. It’s a rare trait.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What do you think about Carrinas’ actions?”

dlgAnsw.text: “What do you think about Carrinas’ actions?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“You did what you have to do. No more, no less. I’m sure you’re aware that you don’t have the authority to make deals on behalf of the Imperial Guards.
“You made the arrangements, which is something I’m willing to overlook because you thought you were acting in our best interests, and passed the information on to me. Your involvement ends now. Understood?”
“Good,” says Paullus heavily.

dlgAnsw.text: “What do you think about Carrinas’ actions?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“And you know that how? I’ve been fighting the Ordu for more than four decades, but you’ve figured them all out after a day at their camp?
“You think that if we help them, feed them, arm them, they’ll become good neighbors all of sudden? Because you showed them the power of love?
“They are warriors, <charname>. They live to fight. It’s in their blood. We give them arms today and tomorrow they will come to test our strength. Not out of malice or anger, but because that’s what they are.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What do you think about Carrinas’ actions?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “I don’t approve of my officers disregarding their orders and the chain of command and doing what they think is right. I don’t approve of emotional decisions either.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What are you going to do with Carrinas?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Teron’s strategic value is zero. We gained nothing there, but forced Gaelius to make a deal with the Ordu. Had we not stopped them, we’d have been in a very difficult situation right now.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What are you going to do with Carrinas?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “We. Pavola acted fast, Bass held his own, Carbo marched day and night to stand with you. If you feel that you alone deserve the credit, you aren’t the <man/woman> I thought you were.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What are you going to do with Carrinas?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “I haven’t decided yet. The damage is already done and moving against Carrinas now will only weaken us further. He can’t do much on his own, other than hold the town. So, at the moment I’m inclined to let him sit there and keep the pressure on Gaelius.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Lord Meru asked for our help. His men want to poke around in some ruins. You will provide operational security while they do it, before escorting them back to Ganezzar.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What does Meru want in the ruins?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “What choice do we have now?” asks Paullus quietly. “Carrinas set the events in motion. Now they’re like a snowball rolling down a hill, gathering in speed and volume. I tried to reach Gaelius and calm him down, but he thought it was a ploy and made a deal with the Ordu. Now Meru is wondering what Gaelius is up to. Evidently, he decided to speed up his own plans and risk a confrontation with House Aurelian.”

“First, he paid us very generously. Pre-war blue steel from his House’s supplies. Gaelius won’t be happy, but after everything that happened I doubt that helping Meru would make much of a difference.
“Second, strengthening Meru will weaken Gaelius and make him more agreeable.”

“Making a deal with us. How long do you think we can continue living like this? We’ve been sitting here, in the middle of nowhere for long enough. We want our share of the pie now, and if we have to help Meru to push Gaelius closer to the negotiation table, so be it.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What does Meru want in the ruins?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Why should we care?”

dlgAnsw.text: “You don’t share Gaelius’ concerns about magic?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “I’m a soldier. I’m not afraid of tools of war. If it comes to it, we can burn Maadoran to the ground using nothing but torches. It will take us longer, but we’ll get the job done. It’s men like us that Gaelius should be afraid of, not some dusty old gadgets.”
“Carrinas tried to force my hand, create a situation that would force us to act. In a sense, he succeeded.”

“After the Empire fell, we were kept outside, like a dog that guards the master’s house but is never allowed in. At first, when there were seven strong Houses, we didn’t have a choice. Now we do. Now it’s Gaelius who doesn’t have a choice. He simply doesn’t know about it yet.
“I think a proper power-sharing deal is possible. Gaelius will rule and we’ll make sure that he rules unopposed, safe against all threats, internal or external. He would be a fool not to take it, but let’s get him to the table first.”
“You’re Carrinas’ <man/woman>. If the mission goes sideways, we can pin it on him. Mind you, I have full confidence in you, but it does pay to be prepared for the worst.”

dlgAnsw.text: “How many men are you going to give me?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Talk to Legatus Raenas about it. See if he can spare any men for this mission.”

“If he can’t?” frowns Paullus as if failing to understand the question. “Centurion, we’re having this conversation because you seem to be a very capable <man/woman>.
“I told the Legatus that I want him to take a look at you and see if you can be of any value to us. I’m confident that you can find a way to prove your worth to him. Think of it as a test.”

“Had you done nothing, you would have been crucified for joining a rogue commander and attacking a peaceful town. Fortunately for you, you’ve proven to be rather capable – or so people say. I’d like to see a demonstration of your abilities.”
